news.name: Jihye Lee Advances to Ph.D. Candidacy in Social Work
news.description: Jihye Lee, a Ph.D. student in Social Work at the Brown School, has advanced to Ph.D. candidacy after completing her area statement and qualifying exam. Her research examines the economic integration of refugees in the United States, with a focus on multidimensional poverty and discrimination. As a candidate, she will continue developing her dissertation using quantitative and mixed-methods approaches to analyze resettlement outcomes, while collaborating with local community partners to connect research and practice.

news.name: Restrictive U.S. Migration Policies Taking a Toll on the Health and Well-Being of Highly Educated Immigrants
news.description: A new paper from the project, published last week in the Journal of Immigrant and Minority Health, examines the emotional and social consequences of U.S. migration policies such as the Travel Ban, family separation, and the uncertainty surrounding immigration processes. The study highlights how these policies fuel emotional distress, family strain, and significant mental health challenges among highly educated immigrants and international students.

news.name: Scholar discusses refugee research (IASFM20 podcast)
news.description: Featured in a conversation with Dr.Naseh and Akino Tahir about our research on the economic integration of resettled refugees in the U.S., emphasizing a multidimensional approach beyond just employment. (Sponsored by WashU and IASFM20).

news.name: Providing Follow-Up Support for a Newly Resettled Afghan Family in St. Louis
news.description: After an initial engagement with refugee support programs, I continued to provide follow-up support for a newly resettled Afghan family in St. Louis. My role included accompanying family members to regular health check-ups and assisting with essential immigration and resettlement paperwork. This ongoing involvement offered a deeper perspective on the long-term challenges that refugee families encounter and reinforced the importance of sustained, community-based support.

news.name: Two from Brown School named fellows by WashUâ€™s Center for Race, Ethnicity & Equity ($2,000)
news.description: Jihye Lee, a PhD student in social work, has been selected as a 2025-2026 Race & Ethnicity Scholar Fellow. This fellowship is awarded annually to three graduate students whose work advances scholarship in race, ethnicity, and equity. Fellows participate in events, workshops, and professional development opportunities, and are encouraged to share their research or creative work with their cohort and center affiliates.

news.name: Graduate Research Assistant Jihye Lee wins the Second Prize in the Social Science Category at the 2025 30th Annual Graduate Research Symposium ($500)
news.description: Jihye Lee, a second-year doctoral student at the Brown School, for winning the Second Prize in the Social Science category at the 2025 30th Annual Graduate Research Symposium at Washington University in St. Louis.

news.name: Brown School Students Gain Hands-On Experience Supporting Refugees in St. Louis
news.description: Students in the Practice with Refugees and Immigrants course at the Brown School have the unique opportunity to work directly with newly resettled refugees in St. Louis, thanks to a collaboration with Welcome Neighbor St. Louis. This local nonprofit provides a range of services for new American families, including volunteer pairings with recently resettled refugees.

news.name: 1:1 Korean Language and Culture Mentoring for Korean-Americans
news.description: Provide weekly 1:1 Zoom mentoring for Korean-Americans, supporting Korean language acquisition, cultural knowledge, and identity exploration

news.name: Center awards seed grants to projects in human rights, gender and migration ($2,500)
news.description: Awarded 2024 Seed Grant for two doctoral students in Washington University in St. Louis ($2,500), Role: PI (Jihye Lee), Co-Pi (Mitra Naseh, Ph.D.): Quality of Life of Highly Educated Iranian Immigrants and Restrictive Migration Policies.

news.name: Graduate Student Conference Travel Grants ($750)
news.description: Awarded Graduate Student Conference Travel Award in Washington University in St. Louis.

news.name: Brown School Students Gain Hands-On Experience Supporting Refugees in St. Louis
news.description: Students in the Practice with Refugees and Immigrants course at the Brown School have the unique opportunity to work directly with newly resettled refugees in St. Louis, thanks to a collaboration with Welcome Neighbor St. Louis. This local nonprofit provides a range of services for new American families, including volunteer pairings with recently resettled refugees.

news.name: Brown School faculty and students receive Global Pilot Research Grants ($2,500)
news.description: Awarded Global Programs Pilot Research Fund in Washington University in St. Louis ($2,500), Role: PI (Jihye Lee), Co-Pi (Mitra Naseh, Ph.D.): Breaking Barriers: Unraveling the Impact of Financial Aid Policies on Social Mobility for DACA Recipients.
tags: Global Impact at the Brown School

news.name: Exploring the Role of Social Position and Administrative Barriers in the Multidimensional Economic Integration of Newly Resettled Afghans in St. Louis
news.description: This project is funded by the WashU Office of the Vice Chancellor for Research and aims to explore the role of administrative barriers as well as social position in the relationship between initial support and multidimensional economic integration among newly resettled Afghans in St. Louis.
tags: the WashU Office of the Vice Chancellor for Research

news.name: Economic Integration and Poverty Among the Newly Resettled Afghans: A Pilot Study
news.description: This pilot study is funded by the Russell Sage Foundation and aims to explore the economic integration of newly resettled Afghans in St. Louis, MO, and Portland, OR from a multidimensional perspective.
